title: Lea Salonga, voice of ‚ÄòMulan‚Äô and Princess Jasmine, to perform at Segerstrom Center
content:
Born and raised in the Philippines, Lea Salonga grew up watching Disney movies and listening to Disney storybook tapes. Never did she imagine, though, that she would grow up to be a real-life, bona fide Disney Princess.

Then, after earning a Tony Award for her portrayal of Kim in the Broadway musical ‚ÄúMiss Saigon‚Äù in 1991, Salonga landed the career break of a lifetime: to be the singing voice of Princess Jasmine in the 1992 hit Disney film ‚ÄúAladdin.‚Äù

Six years later, she got a second chance to live her young girl‚Äôs dream as she performed the vocals of Mulan in the 1998 Disney film of that name.

‚ÄúI never thought when I was 5 and listening to ‚ÄòCinderella‚Äô stories that I‚Äôd be a Disney princess. I think it‚Äôs such a magical thing to happen in my life, and for it to happen twice is something I would never have thought could happen,‚Äù said Salonga in a recent phone interview.

Salonga‚Äôs distinctive voice will return to Southern California for concerts tonight at the Valley Performing Arts Center in Northridge and Saturday at Segerstrom Center for the Arts. Backed by a four-piece band, Salonga will perform a selection of well-known songs, including her greatest hits from her various musicals and films.

‚ÄúWe made sure to choose a fun program that the band is going to dig playing and I‚Äôm going to love singing,‚Äù said Salonga, ‚Äúand because we are having so much fun onstage, I hope that translates to the audience as well.‚Äù

Salonga is keeping the program‚Äôs song selections a secret for now, until she and her musical director decide on the set list; however, she promises all of the tunes will be familiar and fit her vocal range. Some of the songs, she added, will be making their California debut.

‚ÄúThis will be the first time for California audiences to hear these songs, but there is nothing unknown or out of left field; stuff that always makes sense with my voice.‚Äù

A regular feature of Salonga‚Äôs solo concerts is an audience participation segment, in which she chooses someone to join her onstage to sing the Grammy and Academy Award-winning duet ‚ÄúA Whole New World‚Äù from ‚ÄúAladdin.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo need to panic; we always have a lyric sheet so anyone who dares to come up doesn‚Äôt have to have it memorized fully,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI want them to have fun.‚Äù

Salonga has numerous Broadway credits, including her role as Eponine in the 1993 ‚ÄúLes Mis√©rables‚Äù Broadway run and as Fantine in the 2006 Broadway revival. She recently came off Broadway in the new musical ‚ÄúAllegiance,‚Äù which also starred George Takei and Telly Leung.

Splitting her time between the U.S. and Manila, Salonga is a coach on the Philippine version of the television show ‚ÄúThe Voice.‚Äù In addition to her onscreen and onstage career, she has released several solo albums, including ‚ÄúI‚Äôd Like to Teach the World to Sing‚Äù (1997) and ‚ÄúBy Heart‚Äù (1999).

On this tour, Grammy-nominated bass player Trey Henry and drummer Ray Brinker, both from the jazz group Tierney Sutton Band, will back Salonga.

‚ÄúI get to go up onstage with musicians who I really admire and respect, and just have a great time with,‚Äù Salonga said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs thrilling when I get to perform stuff where I can just emotionally let go and fly off to another world in my mind, and the audience gets to ride on that too.‚Äù

Contact the writer: jmoe@ocregister.com
